Cruising the River Seine. You can't help but see the River Seine when you're in Paris. We booked a tour on a sightseeing boat (Paris Tours) and cruised down the Seine, starting near the Eiffel Tower. This gives you a whole new perspective of the Eiffel Tower and different views of both banks. The city looks beautiful at night from the river, with lights illuminating the tower and the museums along the banks. We did a scenic night cruise before heading by bus to the Moulin Rouge Cabaret in Montmartre. It's also nice to walk alongside the river and cross the bridges, our favorite - the Pont Neuf. Another plus is viewing the river from the Ile de la Citie, by the Notre Dame.

Worth checking out!. One of the more beautiful spots to check out in Paris!. Lots of things to see and a lot of the city historic landmarks are close by!. As you'd expect, the area gets very busy during the day!

Lots of fun. Ironically much like south bank in London is one of my favourite places to while away a summer afternoon, wandering along the Seine was what we loved most in Paris. Between all the lovely art installations and free child friendly games and activities we could have easily spent all day here rather than bother with the Tour Eiffel!

Beautiful River front. We visited the Seine river front opposite Eiffel tower during recent visit to Paris.It's an impressive place where one could take a boat ride to enjoy the city sights or enjoy a meal at the cafes or just sit cosy on the banks of the river. We were lucky to catch the cruise on the second attempt as the previous day apparently there was no boating due to flooding in the Seine.The view of the Seine waterfront from the Eiffel is fabulous too

A great way to see some parts of Paris. We took a tour on the River Seine which was included in the Paris Pass. It allows you to take a good picture of Eiffel Tower as the tour part of this Pass starts close to the base of Eiffel Tower. You take an hour cruise down the Seine river, you see the Musee D'Orsay, Eiffel Tower, bridges and Cathedral etc

No hustle and bustle. When in the French capitol, it is a must to take a boat trip down the Seine, the whole experience gives you a better outlook and perspective of the city. Relax and wath the city pass by without the hustle and bustle of motor traffic and crowds

River of Love. River Seine has been captured in many movies. Whatever scene it may be, this river is a monument in its own right where it brings out the love, joy, sentimental and romantic element in a person.That was the feeling I felt even without my loved one standing next to me. There was an air of magic!This river is best experienced by a river cruise. And of course with your beloved.

"Night cruise on the Seine river". no wonder Paris is called City of Love.. Seine flows right through the heart of Paris... there are around 32 beautiful bridges on this river each having different architectural aspect...The Oldest bridge is the Pont Neuf ...Another popular bridge is the Pont Des Arts, which differs from many other bridges in that it is constructed of metal and is entirely pedestrian.This bridge is called the lovers bridge.... if in Paris never miss this cruise on River Seine

Beautiful short trip. We bought two 2 day bus tour tickets & a 1 hour trip down the seine for 90 euros from Big B tours. The bus tickets last for any 2 consecutive days and the river cruise can be used on any day. The trip down the seine in the sunshine was great with information coming from a hand held speaker which had loads of stories of buildings & statues. As soon as we got off the boat we had lunch right next to the boat stop on the Seine, 2 mains, 2 desserts & 2 soft drinks for 33 euros...a good price for good food - which is nice!

Seine River tour of Illuminated Paris. I took a nighttime tour of the river Seine which highlighted attractions on the both left & right banks & the bridges overhead & their history. The boat was comfortable & provided excellent views & the recorded narration was interesting & thorough. Loved this!
Awesome . You should definitely go on a boat ride down the river Seine. Such a romantic experience and you are able to see all the sightings.

A lot to do around the Seine. Definitely a must see when in Paris. Well it's hard to miss it! We did an evening cruise to see the city light up at night. On Saturday nights at the Seine by the Latin Quarter there's a small square at the Seine and people dance and others watch! You could always just take a romantic stroll along the Seine, or take some wine and snacks and sit along the Seine and wave to the boats that go by. I also noticed on Saturday nights at the Seine near Pont Alexander Bridge, there is a nice crowd that congregates at the Seine where they have what looked like food vendors and a more lively feel.
very nice experience and views of paris. It is highly recommended to take such a cruise The cruise give you the opportunity to see most major attraction of parisincluding the beutifull bridges

Seine River can be a wonderful way to visit Paris. I had the opportunity to ride a bike through the historical Paris by bordering the River Seine. My family and I enjoy it tremendously. We brought lunch and eat next to the river.

And experience not to be missed.. We had visited Paris once before in October of 2013. This second time we visited in August of 2015. During our first visit, we didn't walk down by the river Seine. This time we did, and I'm so glad we did. The river comes alive during the summer. There are many wonderful restaurants with outdoor seating. I particularly remember one called Flow which has lounge chairs and seved great burgers and beer. Hundreds of people, including lots of families walk, bike, rollerblade along the river. Many stop for a bite to eat and some even bring their own packed picnics. During the evening it is great to see and waive at the many cruises which are seeing going down the river.
Nice & clean. Coming from Brisbane, I am not use to seeing clean rivers but the river seine was beautiful and clean. During the day it looks so blue!
Refreshingly Beautiful. We stayed a week in Paris and walked along the Seine, stood watching it and the interesting boats that travel it, and crossed over it numerous times. Very pleasant and clean.
Paris in lights. Being a balmy night decided to take cruise on the river seine as the light was fading the lights of paris started to glow . Paris, lights and romance !!!!!

A route into the heart of a city. The Seine is crucial to Paris. Most great cities sit on aOr astride a river, Paris is no exception. Ride on a bateau mouches and explore the city from a different perspective. You can get on at the Pont de l'Alma, close by the tunnel where Princess Diana's car crashed. There are happier sights from the boat, including a copy of the Statue of Liberty, which was a gift from France to America.

Worth a stroll along, especially on a good-weather day!. The city of Paris is quite small, and so you'll find yourself near the River Seine quite a lot. There are some stunning bridges leading off the main walkways that offer a lovely view of Paris, and many of them are crowd-free (an advantage you won't get at most of the city's monuments).. if you have the time and weather on your side, take a stroll!
Enjoyable. Lovely trip along the seine lasting about an hourVery informative about all the landmarksWas very enjoyable but if it had been raining it would be a different story.

Amazing. For the first visit to Paris, but not only, a cruise on the Seine is among the top things to do in the city of the light. I recommend the evening cruise on the Seine.It is more than magnificent.

Magnificent!. There is nothing like a Vedette ride on the Seine especially if the weather is nice. You get the opportunity to see the city of Paris from another view while you relax and enjoy the peace of the ride. Ypu can kiss your loved one under every bridge. Have fun!
Wonderful Views. it is a must to take a river cruise on the Seine best way to see many of the sights. I recommend the hop on hop off river tours

Seine river cruise and 3 course meal is a must when visiting Paris. We enjoyed a river cruise on the Seine with a three course meal organised by Paris City Tours. Had a wonderful two hours enjoying the meal and taking in the scenery
Seine River Brunch. Planning a River Cruise is a great way to see Paris city attractions and details of the bridges. A must see.

Interesing excursion.. Athough we don't like this type of excursions, we booked a 1 hour tour, starting at the Pond Neuf. It was very interesting. The guide was very nice and explained very clearly in French and English.

The beauty of Paris. This river is at the heart of Paris and is an important part of daily life and touristic activities. Most of the attractions are located near this river. A boat ride in the river will be breathtaking. Expensive but a dinner cruise would be awesome. The views from the river are incredible. Even the view of the river from top of Eiffel tower is magnificent.

Bateaux Mouche. If you've only a short amount of time in Paris and want to see a lot, hop on a boat tour. It's the quintessential tourist thing to do and, on a nice day, is truly lovely. The evening boat rides are also fun and often come with some delicious fare.

We loved the Seine cruise. We did the cruise in the evening. Best time to go is 9:15, that way you can see the Eiffel Tower light up. The cruise was great. You see many sights and with the relaxing pace of the cruise, you're sure to enjoy.

What a view!. You have to see Paris from the river. Many different boats provide a sightseeing cruise of the river. To see Notre Dame from the river is amazing. Our tickets were 14 Euro per person and were well worth it. Would highly recommend for a different perspective of Paris.
Tour. Just a river tour up * down a small portion of the Seine in mid-town Paris. English headset available that was very descriptive. Don't go on a hot sunny day.

Beautiful spot along the Seine River. Between Pont de l'Alma and Pont Alexandre is a great spot to have a picnic. There are also some restaurants along the river if picnicking is not what you are into. There are some toilets too. This area is very busy during the day and night with walker, cyclist and people just enjoying the fresh air.

River cruise worth taking. We took the river cruse and found it a great way to see and enjoy Paris from a differnt perspective . . we took the later afteroon trip just as the sun was setting and it was amazing . . slight low summer storm cloud gave is the most amazing sunset views as we rode along under the bridges and waterfront buildings . . Norte Dame was stunning . .
Seine in Family. It is a very good experience, dinner over the Seine, good meal (Not to big, if you wants to have a light dinner is perfect) and a very nice service.
Love spending time around. It's always magical to walk around, to watch people on a boat, to spend time with your friends or partner. Makes Paris how it is... <3

Nicer than going on the bus!. Take one of the many boat trips - we used the 'Batobus' which has 9 stops, takes around 2 hours to complete, but which you can hop on and off as many times as you want for the duration of your ticket (1 day, 2 days, or more). A lovely way to get around the main sights around the Seine.

I would reommend any of the larger bateaux cruises to really see Prais from the Seine.. WE took the Seine trip as part of the open top bus deals. These work brilliantly together as they are basically hop on, hop off, and you then can add the boat trip from two destinations whenever it suits. Its a great way to view Paris from another perspective.

Great walk without crowds and hustlers. I really enjoyed walking along the banks of the River Seine. I was expecting it to be like westminster bridge full or crowds and hustlers but it was much more peaceful and relaxed. I would recomend.
Must add to your list to do in Paris. What spectacular views and photo moments to last a life time. Great tour guide, would highly recommend this river cruise

Informative and soothing . The river seine boat tickets were included in the big bus company tour price. We got off the hop on hop off bus at Eiffel Tower and walked across. A bit of a queue but it moves fast. It's hot on the outside upstairs section unless you are there early or later in the day. Alternatively use the inside. No aircon but you have access to a telephonic guide which is informative. Vending machines line the walls so you can purchase snacks and drinks. A calm tour. Lasts a hour.

Nice and Breezy. A spent a quiet moment at the Seine and it was very nice to sit and enjoy the breeze after an eventful day in Paris although to be honest I wasn't very fond of the trash in the water.

interesting. We went by boat up and down the river at night. The boat was okay - pretty basic and fortunately not very many people on board (would imagine a full complement would be a bit uncomfortable) so we were able to walk around and see everything. The bridges had interesting art/sculptures on them. The Eiffel Tower was all lit up and the riverside buildings were all illuminated. Very pretty - would have been even better if our boat had had a liquor licence - a glass of wine, a warm night, and all the illuminations would have been noteworthy - had it all except the wine - next time maybe as we'd like to do it again
Special. It was the birthday of our friend and we commemorate in the boat through the river seine seeing Paris at night. A moment to remember forever...

Very pleasant boat 🚣 trip on the river. The journey was nice, I had a chance to stay on the top part of the boat although it was very crouded. The weather was good and had the chance to rake plenty of pictures of the Eiffel Tower and other places and land marks of paris.

Bon voyage sue les Vedettes de Pont Neuf. My wife and I enjoyed a wonderful late evening cruise on the Vedettes de Pont Neuf. The cruise is magical, once the sun has set and the Eiffel Tower by night even more spectacular!
The commentary helped enormously and do book on line to save several euros.
a good rest time. River tour is a nice break from the lines and has interesting places to see and a must in my book just as a rest time. Not fantastic but okay.

Tour in the night on river Seine. I was there with my friends and we really enjoyed the tour with the ship on the river. We also tried to understand the explanations of the in foreign languages which was really interesting. I will recomend everyone that's in Paris and walk all day long. To take time and go with some ship on Seine river to rest a little bit.

Excellent , must do.. Must do!Very nice boat tour, you can see everything.Big boat , when you boarding the boat they will take your picture and you can purchase it at the end € 10.00.You will see Notre Dame, Louvre and many more.We enjoyed it.

Boat ride down the River Seine. We took the river cruise down the Seine at night. This is a must do when you come to Paris. You will understand why Paris is called the City of Lights. The city is beautiful all lite up at night. It is so romantic at night!!

Lazy afternoon strolling the Seine. Had the great opportunity to wander part of the River Seine with my young nieces/nephews and family. probably covered just under 2km from near Notre Dame to the Eiffel Tower on the western bank. What a find!!!!!! Run, walk or stroll no one seems to care how you do it. Plenty of food/drinks if that's your thing and several spots for the kids to entertain themselves. This stretch of the river is a benchmark for river fronts around the world. Something for everyone and all paces.
Relaxing. The river seine is worth every penny we enjoyed the ride and learnt a lot from the tour guide would do this again.

Take a Seine River Cruise. it's worth it.. This is another must see/do while in Paris. We took the river cruise and it was spectacular. The boat moves slowly in a large loop so you can enjoy all the sites and see them again.The food was very good for a venue like this and the staff very attentive.
River cruise . Did a 7.30pm cruise. A lovely way to end a very busy and very hot day. Worth doing but my only criticism was that there was no where on board to buy drinks.

Walking down the Seine. I walked form Notre Dame down along the Seine to the Eifel Tower. It was a long beautifully relaxing walk. The aptmosphere was so relaxed yet Lively, it was a fantastic experience.

A Wondrous Walk. A walk down the River Seine is a must. Such a beautiful river with stunning views all around, couldn't have asked for better to be honest. There are also places to take a boat tour however we walked instead as we could stop and take pictures and explore the local area. The Eiffel Tower is also near by so it is a must see place if you're in Paris

A Romantic Must in Paris. We have walked the sidewalks that line the Seine every time we are there and still find something fun and exciting to see. This year, it was all the barges that were moored along the banks with their interesting artwork and designs. Walked it both at night and during the day.
Take a boat tour. It's the canal that runs all the way through paris and it's beautiful, I suggest you take a tour of the river on one of the many tour boats.
Wonderful Seine. Trip down the seine makes you appreciate the surroundings and provides you with a perspective of the best attractions to see. You must do thiswhen visiting paris.

batobus. The batobus is a hop on and hop off boat. You can board at one of many locations along the river Seine. There is no commentary but do not let this stop you. The boat passes by many of the landmarks of Paris and you can disembark at the Louvre the musee d'orsay and the Eiffel tower amongst others. I think I am right in remembering that you can hop off and back on another one when you have visited your place of choice and use the same ticket again.
Nice place for a walk. There is lots to see and do just by walking along the River. There are restaurants, entertainment, and of course boat tours.

Great cruise. You must try it. You will be able to see Paris from the river. It is very beautiful cruise If you walk on the river, you will see a very nice view of many couples hanging locks to it bridges. A very romantic sign. Throughout the banks, there are different cafes and restaurants too. Additionally, you can see artists who sit everywhere painting tourists and natural views.
Seine river cruise. wonderful 2 hour cruise down the river. Such beautiful scenery with English commentary. I'm sure we saw things not viewed by the road.

Magnificent view of the Eiffel Tower from the River Seine !. My husband and I took one of the River Seine boat rides for a fee and had a great view of the Eiffel Tower and other tourist spots. I highly recommend that you take one of the boat rides to have a different view of the Eiffel Tower and other tourist spots.
Worth the money. It is not a tourist trap. It is a great place to start to know the city by water. It is a hour long. However, take your own water each water cost 7,50 euro.
River Cruise!. If you only do 1 thing whilst in Paris, it must be a river boat trip. We took a cruise from Notre Damn to the Eiffel Tower and back and it was the highlight of our visit.

Ride a bike without the traffic. After a visit to the Eiffel tower or the Musee de Orsay you can hire a bike for a ride along the Seine very cheaply. There are many bike stations along the river bank, with bikes free for 30min and only a few euro for longer. You do need a MasterCard or Visa card to guarantee that you will return the bike - otherwise a 150 euro fee applies. It took my daughter and I several attempts to get it all happening - be patient when you insert the card and wait until you are asked for the PIN number, otherwise your card may be rejected. After registering, you recieve a paper ticket with a code number that must be keyed in to the other side of the lecturn/machine and then you can choose the bike number. Check to see that the tyres are pumped up (it is very hard work trying to ride with a flat tyre!). Bikes do not need to be returned to the same station and you do not need to wear a helmet. We rode along the walkway on a sunny Saturday in August, and did not have to worry about vehicles, only avoiding people, which was delightful.

evening river cruise. This was a great trip down the Seine as it gives you a wonderful view of the classic buildings from the river side with an accompanied narration of the history of the buildings themselves. It is also a good way to rest your tired feet at the same time as you tour. I believe this is a must.

A day in Paris. We pre-booked with GetYourGuide and got a combo ticket for a river cruise and the Louvre. Worth it to queue jump and the river cruise was so relaxing and a great way to see the sights.

Just beautiful. ... We did the Seine River at night and it was such a beautiful serene picturesque view from the boat cruise. It was about 2 hours long and we got to see many cites from the river and it was well worth it.

Go visit on a boat!. We took a stroll down by the banks the last time we were there and there is always something to see, acts and music etc. A few years ago we took a boat trip down it and it's a great experience for couples. Well worth a trip.

Follow the River to Major Landmarks while enjoying local merchants. Put down the map for a minute and follow the river to find small parks and precious little places that will make your walk all the more enjoyable
Paris France. NIce beautiful river with a lot of fantastic sighte to see, did not take the river tour as it was raining . but did walk along the banks and took a lot of amazing pictures at night
Seine River Cruise a must.. Lunch Cruise along the Seine on a Bateaux de Parisienne. Perfect food, live music, flowing wine and sights a plenty. Excellent. Highly recommended.
Beautiful . We walked along the river. Very romantic and scenic. We walked by the padlock bridge at notre dame and also chilled on the river taking in the views.
River Cruise on the Seine. Loved our river cruise down the Seine. Very historical and beautiful! There were a few little cafe's along the Seine and cute towns and shopping.

Picturesque!. One of the most picturesque river in Europe. Great place for an afternoon stroll or a morning walk. There's a lot stalls selling souvenirs and used goods along the river bank. Plenty of cafes for coffee breaks and light meals.

Avalon Cruise from Paris to Normandy. We spent days wondering around the Seine & went on an Avalon Paris to Normandy cruise for 8 days. It was magical. The boat was brand new and amazing and the food was fantastic. The view from our boat was amazing, we were truly amazed the whole time. Would recommend Avalon and will do the cruise again.For a real look at the beautiful Seine this cruise took us in and out of little towns and villages and provided wonderful tours. The Seine is a wonderful river to spend time on.
Beautiful!. Its so lovely to stroll down the banks of the Seine River! I highly recommend having a nice picnic or a boat tour!

A Wonderful Walk Along the Seine. We had a great time walking along the river Seine, from the Eiffel Tower area to the the Saint Germaine area (in which we detoured in order to go to Laduree!) There are lots of fun stops with things to do for the kids (mine are 12, 14 and 16) along the way. DO NOT MISS the sparkling water fountain!
The Life of Paris. The blood of Paris...go on a boat ride...sit on the banks, walk the walkways...it is beautiful and romantic...a must see and do while here.
A seine cruise. If you want to sit a chill for a bit, get a Seine cruise, Not particularly expensive and you get quite a good view of some of the main attractions.

The amazing bridges of Paris. This trip took place on a rainy day but we stayed in the inside cabin of the boat and were comfortable. There also were some open points from which to take pictures without getting wet. The commentary that ran throughout the hour long trip was interesting. We went from Pont Neuf down to the Eiffel Tower then turned around and cruised past the two islands. Definitely worth doing whatever the weather.
Lovely Walk. Nice just to walk beside the Seine while eating crepes and watching the boats pass by. Lots of bridges to explore - each with it's own style.Separate lane for walking and biking.
I imagined it more beautiful. Taking into account the romantic fame it has, I thought it would be nicer, a lovely place, kind of garden or park to walk through, no just a road next to the river.
Must do!. The Seine River cruise is a must! It gives a relaxing, informative and beautiful perspective to this great city. I found the ride so peaceful and relaxing after a busy day of sightseeing.

The Seine Cruise - as romantic as can be!. WE went in the peak of summer, and yet, accessing the seine River cruise was easy. First we had a lovely lunch, or rather brunch, by the bank of the river, right under the giant shadow of the Eiffel Tower, in Cafe La Teressa. Pizza and wine. It was sumptuous. Then we purchased the inclusive tickets and boarded the cruiser. It was a great trip. @ hours long, traversing through all the major sights of the city of Paris, with a very articulate and comprehensive audio commentary about each of the landmarks as we cross them. And all this while sipping the house champagne that is included in the ticket price. Even our 10 year old son found it all very immersive and fascinating. A memorable tryst with history and romance!

An enjoyable walk.. My husband and I walked along the seine around Norte dame in the evening and there were areas where people were dancing. In one part. They were dancing salsa and in another the Argentinian tango. Older people were teaching younger how to do the dance. Great to watch and lots more to see.

So-So. We were told to go on the boat tour at night as all the buildings are lit up but we found very little that was interesting on the night tour. Notre Dame was beautiful but the real "sight" from the boat is the amount of people on the riverbanks. I'll go again someday but I'll go during the day or perhaps sunset.
Glad we did it. This was a great one hour cruise. We did it as part of an Eiffel Tower and sunset champagne cruise combo.

Great. Take a water taxi cruise it's anlively way to see most of the main sights we could hop on and off all day and was much better than getting on and off the trains. Very relaxing and my son loved being on a boat and looking for the stops on the map
Beautiful river beautiful city. A river cruise is highly recommended to see some amazing Paris sights but also don't forget to take a slow walk along the river!

Magnificent . You can take a walk on the river side among the trees or do it by bike (numerous rentable bikes are available). Try the lower side where you can find some places to snack/drink and exercise.There are lots of photo spots on the way and it's enjoyable during the day as well as during the evening. Plus you can enjoy Paris from an original perspective !

Romantic river. This river that winds around Paris separates the Left Bank and Right Bank. A cruise will take you past sites like the Eiffel Tower and sculptures. Picturesque were wide pedestrian walks with high walls next to the river and boats that served as restaurants tied up along side. Although I cruised along during the day, I imagine a night ride would be quite romantic.I remember learning a song in French about the Seine River in high school French class. Here I was riding over it!

Paris by water. If you would like to see Paris from a different angle, this is the way to do it! A relaxing, hour long boat trip on the Seine where you get to see many famous landmarks from a different perspective. It's definitely worth the time.
Classic. Walking along the Seine enjoying a cup of coffee, champagne, taking in the views and they are plentiful, crossing the bridges

Great cruise. You definitely have to do one of these cruises. They last about 1 hr 20 mins. You get to see all the beautiful sights Paris has to offer. We got our cruise Included in the 'paris pass' so didn't have to pay.
Queue was a little long, however it was all worth it.
A nice way to see some sights . Well worth a river trip down the seine, very relaxing and not too expensive. Its a nice way to see some of paris other than driving so well worth going.

dancing and picnicking on the Seine.. During the summer months there is dancing on the banks of the Seine. The event is free and you can choose the type of dancing you prefer. There is rock n roll, salsa, Argentine tango, folk dancing. The number 63 bus goes there as well as the metro.

Important Landmark River. Because we took a river cruise with Ama-Waterways, we saw a great deal of this river from Paris northward. I enjoyed seeing such a famous landmark, but prefer less developed rivers. Warning spring rains often cause the river to rise too high for river boat traffic to clear the many bridges. We were fortunate to be bused back to Paris on our return. Those departing when we returned had their tours converted to bus tours. We were able to unpack and enjoy our cabins aboard our boat.
A Must Do Trip. Take a trip along the Seine to a taste of Paris life, there's so much to see, the bridges and landmarks and riverside restaurants. A must do.

Once but once is enough.. I went on a river cruise along the Seine and back and I don't know if it's just because of my age or what that I didn't really love it. It was a lovely view seeing all of the French buildings along the Seine but I was just very bored very quickly!

クルーズを通じてパリを実感できるパリのシンボル　You can see typical Paris through crusing. セーヌ川は眺めるものでなく、クルーズするもの。シテ島を一周するクルーズで、典型的なパリが見えるので、一度はクルーズしたい。River Seine is for crusing to see Paris but not to see itself. You will find typcal and all of Paris through cruising thus it is the must.
Lovely walk. . We had a lovely walk along the river from the Eifel Tower to Le Louvre. The walk is pleasant with a few points of interest along the way.

Take a boat tour. Great to walk along the banks of the Seine on a glorious day but a boat cruise is not to be missed. Even though the boat was rather full you could see everything and the commentary made it all more interesting. Arriving at Notre Dame to hear the bells tolling is very atmospheric!! Great fun and not too expensive.

Cruising The Seine. What an awesome way to see some of the major sites in Paris. A boat cruise is a very touristy activity to do but one of the more relaxing ways to see the sites. A nice option is to do a dinner cruise.

Main Highway thru Paris. Highly recommend that you take a bateau mouche and especially in the evening, it will be crowded, as Paris always seems to be, but you will glide by museums, churches {Notre Dame} and get a distant view of the Eiffel Tower. I wouldn't go except at sunset or early evening. The boats are lighted as well. Great opportunity to relax a bit, get some photos along the way. If you go to the top of the Eiffel Tower, you can also get some great photos of the River. Consider it the main highway thru Paris. I personally wouldn't recommend walking beside it, we saw too many questionable people drinking and hanging out along the riverside. But it is a great way to see many sites if you have limited time.

Bigger than life.. This is one of those sights that one is haunted with till you see it. Watch it from atop the Eiffel towers, walk along it, sit on one of the bridges,stare at it. It is just there,it lets you get in touch with your feelings.

So romantic. The place seemed boring looking in the picture so I didn't expect much but it turned out to be so good. We went on the boat along the river and it was so romantic ( we were on honeymoon). I could also see French in many different view from both sides of the review! Don't miss that!

Great area for a stroll through Paris. Walked along the shores of the Seine on a glorious summer day from the Eiffel Tower to the Museum D'Orsay. There is a very nice and clean gravel path for bikers, walkers with benches along the way. Many people just sitting and relaxing too.

Relaxing boat tour along the Seine.. From the Tulleries, walking along the river Seine was relaxing and gave a unique glimpse of life along the river. We booked a boat tour from Bateau Mouche which was popular and therefore a 20 minute wait for the launch. This is a great way to see many iconic landmarks including the Eiffel Tower and Notre Dame from a distance. The trip takes an hour and a half.
Cruise the Seine.. Did a cruise and that was worthwhile. We did a 1 hour cruise, which was part of our 'Paris Pass'. Boat was full but still quite enjoyable, especially on a sunny day.

Stroll Day and Night. During our recent one week stay in Paris we took the opportunity to stroll the banks of the River Seine every day. When you visit check out the riverbanks during the day and night as they are very different experiences.
Nice walk. The river Seine offers you a nice walk. Along the way you can find some activities and food to buy, so it is very pleasent

Boat tour and more . The river runs through the city and there are many things to enjoy. While we were there, a temporary sand pit was set up with lounge chairs and playgrounds for children, as well as gelato stands for those hot summer days. There are several boat cruises that run along the river for about an hour which gives a different perspective of the city. Along the way you will see the Eiffel Tower, Notre Dame, the grand palace and more. You will also pass under many of the bridges, each unique in their own way. If you want to be truly parisian, head down to the river in the evening with a light picnic and bottle of wine, and watch the sunset. Simply beautiful!

Lovely cruise. Enjoyed the boat cruise early afternoon, not too busy or loud and quite chilled and the audio information was really interesting, the view of the Notre Dame and the Lourveare stunning from the river. Think it was around 14 euros for the cruise.

River seine. Our hotel looked onto the river, pretty, clean and lots going on, a man made beach very busy though. Went to the bride with all the lovers locks. Postcard and art sellers along the Bridges, boat busily going back and forth. Nice to watch the world going by. Streets packed
Relaxing tour. Went of the river illumination tour. It was crowded but worth it. Lovely to sit, relax and take in the view.
take a boat. i boot tour through viator.com with dinner in the boat , so Romanic and amazing food. the view of Eiffel tower is awesome
Walking the river was amazing. I walked both sides of the river during our two week stay. It really is beautiful and easy with a baby and stroller. I would definitely reccommend

Relaxed river with mainly tourist cruises. This river runs through the city of Paris and offers a beautiful view of the city. The river has several boat and tour companies that offer dinner cruises and sight seeing cruises departing from the Eiffel Tower. The boats vary in size and many are very large packing hundreds of people into one boat. The river is calm and wide in the city. Its worth a visit and a ride down the river.
Tour cruise!. We booked a tour cruise. It was 10€ per person for 1 hour. We saw a lot of attractions and we learnt more about them. It was very beautiful!

Great views. No trip to Paris is complete without a walk along the River Seine. It's romantic and picturesque, even in the rain. It's always nice and breezy along the river even during summer. You can walk over to the other side of Paris via one of the many pedestrian bridges across the River Seine. There are many opportunities for great photos and selfies along the river. So be sure to get your cameras and cellphones ready.
Romantic VIew. Very fantastic view along the Seine River.We did select other tour ( not famous one ) that less people and enjoyed the SAME view.

So nice to go for a stroll or sit down and have a picnic alongside the beautiful Seine. So nice to go for a stroll or sit down alongside the Seine. The atmosphere is typically French and not so much of a touristic highlight. That's why I loved it so much.
great views. A lovely way to see Paris along the water, a commentary is given. We went during the day, but I am sure the evening cruise is equally as enjoyable

NICE VIEW. A great option to have some outdoor fun but during the summer it´s really really hot
and unfortunately people use to leave garbage everywhere
Glorious and charming. The river cruises are a must if visiting Paris. You get to see the fantastic culture and designs. The Seine is a glorious experience as one of the major rivers in the world.
Great for a walk. lovely place for a walk, so many beautiful sights and bridges to appreciate along the way, never took a cruise but they looked good, much prettier and cleaner than the Thames.

Sailing anyone?. This is the river that winds through Paris providing a valuable water way for industry as well as tourism. River cruise are available for all over Paris and for inexpensive prices. Usually 1 hour long. Also dinner cruises, A Great way to see the highlights of Paris.

Relaxing views, great way to explore. We spent an afternoon on a river boat cruising the Seine. Didn't actually fancy it too much but was surprised what a nice relaxing experience this was. A great way to see Paris from a different perspective.
Cruising on the Seine. Do the river cruise worth the money, lovely aspect of Paris from the water, great photo moments, see most of the main sights as you cruise along the Seine

Just relaxing.... Always great to walk along the river bank and even nicer to sit down and watch the boats pasing by. Make sure to have enough time to explore many stand selling old items.
This city lives with the river...

Smell of urine spoils a beautiful walk!. On our last night in Paris we decided to talk a walk along the seine. We walked from st-germain Pont arts to pont de sully which is a beautiful stretch of the seine alongside Notre-Dame and the louvre. Lots of locals enjoying picnics, drinking and music and really got a feel for Parisian life. The only thing that spoilt the beautiful walk was the strong stench of urine when walking under the bridges which is such a shame. Id expect the city council to be regularly cleaning the areas as it really is a spoiler on such a beautiful walk.
Vibrant and interesting. Beautiful river to walk along its banks, admiring the bridges, enjoying the views, sipping the coffee in a small cafe or browsing through one of its street markets.

Boat ride at sunset. we took a tour boat ride from Pont Nuef. There are many other places on both sides of the river to take this tour. We took a late one in order to see the Eiffel Tower all lit up. It was gorgeous!

A must while in Paris. A visit to Paris is not complete without a cruise on the Seine, many cruise boats available most leave every half hour on the hour. Best seen as the sun is setting bye the time the time you get back the old lady will at her best with the lights on don't forget the light show every hour.

Walk along. The view along the river with the boats passing by is lovely. The bridges are fun to look off in the distance from looking down at the many tourists have a ride along the river. Take a walk and enjoy.

Vibrant. This is such a vibrant river with so much going on on the banks. When we visited there was even a beach between the Pont Neuf and Pont de Sully bridges and an antiques market at the Pont Alexander III.
It is lovely to stroll along the banks of the river and cross the many bridges.

Romantic Evening in Paris!. We thoroughly enjoyed the evening boat ride along the Seine and getting to see the Eiffel Tower twinkling and Notre Dame standing out among the buildings of old and new. We loved going under the famed bridges and enjoying the cool night air. Yes! This is worth the money!

Paris is a must see, spend time on the River Seine. Take the River Cruise - Worth it.. You must go to Paris once in your life. The Locks of Love still exist. and is such a romantic thing to do. We got engaged accross from the Eifel Tower overlooking the River Seine. It will always be special. You should see it.

Nice ride . A tour in the river seine is all what you can have in paris if you have little time to spend there this i s the closes that you can be to most of the sites in such a little time .
Really nice

River Seine cruise by evening. This cruise was a highlight of Paris. We chose to do the evening cruise so we could view the Eiffel Towere lit up at night, very romantic.
Plenty of crusies availbale, tickets can be purchased on the day if required.

Lovely stroll at sunset. Walk along River Seine and stroll across the bridges to truly feel like a Parisian. Filled with cafes and artist markets alongside, there's plenty to see while you take in the scenic views. And hey, why not commission an artist to painting you while you're at it.

european vacation. You can take a boat and enjoy a lovely dinner or lunch on the river, which seems romantic to me. I also enjoyed walking on the River front watching people as they also walked or sat to talk.

do it at night. It gives an overall idea of the quality and scope of the monuments of the city without killing your legs and feet. I have done day and night cruises and I think night is more dramatic for sure.
Staff trip to Paris. Spent an afternoon on the Seine on one of the [smaller] bateaux mouche; we took all of our staff to paris for a weekend and this was one of the highlights.
Fun, Food, Fashion on River. Every EU country has river cruise but Paris has different and unique experience. Very very beautiful, must visit!

Loved the boat tour!. Took a boat tour during the day which was amazing, there was indoor and outdoor areas to sit so it depends on your preference due to the heat. Went by lots of monuments and had an english translation of the narration. Loved it and so did my 1 year old!

Good way to spend a day in Paris. Hoping on to one of the boats will help in covering some of the key landmarks in Paris. While in Paris, we had kept a day dedicated for Siene River cruise and was well worth it.

It's always around, so you can choose the time to see it. Scenic and impressive.. Walked along the river's edge several times and even took one of the ferries around the Seine, very peaceful and very calming, beautiful and you can do it anytime. Many people like to hang out and suntan along the banks in certain areas also. I crossed many bridges over the Seine, great photo opportunities everywhere.

Talk an amble along this beauty. I've been told about it. I've seen it broadcast on media. I've dreamt about it. Now I've seen and walked along it. Take the time to walk along this beautiful stretch of The Seine in Paris. There are so many free and paid things to do. Every bridge and walkway holds another treasure. Amazing!

Beautiful way to spend some time. Wandering along the left bank was lovely , very Parisienne! Take a criuse along the river to see Paris in a different light, just beautiful..would love to do this again

Nothing special.... My partner and I had walked along The Seine River which was a leisurely stroll until the ever so strong scent of urine infiltrates your nostrils which ushers you to move a lot quicker. Other parts are fine with ice cream stops and fun stuff, just choose carefully which part you walk on...

Nice to stroll along but rather crowded. All sorts of interesting things along the banks including a beach complete with sand and sandcastles. Not enough toilets, and those we used were very dark. The portaloos are lit through the roof but no light under the bridge.

River with a view!!!. so peaceful yet so much happening around the river!! You can walk, jog, cycle, skate, eat, drink , exercise or just sit on the benches and enjoy the view anytime of the day or night!!!
just relax and enjoy!!!

touristy but fun and worth the monies. Boat trips are usually SO touristy and this is no exception but you still want to do it, what a great way to see the city. takes off right in front of the Eiffel tower, sit and have champagne that you can take with you on the boat

A Beautiful Boat Trip on the Seine. A boat tour is an excellent way to see Paris, especially a sunset tour. The boats depart from right in front of the Eiffel Tower and pass under many beautiful bridges and by many famous landmarks, including Notre Dame, etc. The boats leave about every 30 minutes and it's a bit of a zoo during prime tourist season (we were there in August) - I had wished we bought our tickets in advance as we had to wait in line about 45 minutes to buy tickets. When the weather is nice, as it was during our visit, everyone wants to sit up top on the boats, and luckily we were at the front of the line boarding our boat and were able to secure good seats at the very back of the boat where the views were best. Leaving a bit before sunset is ideal - you leave during daylight, but it's dark by the time you return and in our case, the Eiffel Tower was beautifully lit up, and did it's 5-minute (on the hour) light show just as we approached. Just beautiful!
A free beautiful attraction in Paris.. Take a stroll over one of the many bridges in Paris to view this lovely river...or sit down one one of the banks and have a nice picnic.

Batobus for non narrated hop on/off. For great views and some quality time in the water use Batobus. Very reasonable cost and discount for students. It can get very hot on a 80+ degree day but they frequently will open the glass roof to allow a nice breeze to flow through.

Cruising on the River Seine. The cruise on the River Seine was exhilarating. To drift down the river between the beautiful architecture took me back into time. I am a history buff and to see areas that I often read about meant so much to me. The cruise boat had phones or you could use earbuds to hear the description of each area and noted significance of the different buildings, in several different languages. I very strongly recommend the cruising down the river.

River "get aways". Enjoy a walk along the river, stop to enjoy the "summer beach", enjoy the views from one of the many bridges, or take an evening river cruise to see the lights to come up in the city. The river offers lots of choices.

Beautiful river - nice walk along. It is lovely to walk along the river to the Eiffel Tower. I would recommend a boat tour along the river too. Lovely to see the attractions from a different perspective.
Seine. I was not lucky enough (and did not have time unfortunately) to go via boat on the river, however walked its bank and through its bridges. River Seine is a must see in Paris!

Very pleasant. We took a cruise on the River Seine. It was very pleasant. Lasted about an hour. It gives you a different view of the city than you have when you are traveling on foot or by car. You will see some things that you would not otherwise see. The boat had drinks for sale which was nice because it was very hot.

Best after dark. Great way to see the city at night. All the buildings are lit up and the night life along the shore starts up. make sure you sit up top. The tour will talk about what is on the right side of the boat.

A river with great view. I highly recommend doing a picnic with fresh bread, cheeses, and wine on the "Beach".
Bring a towels and enjoy.
A dinner cruise in the Seine is a must to experience Paris in a great way. The cruise takes you up the river and down. The views are breathtaking all along the way.

Relaxing way to see some of the sights in 60 mins. We (Couple) went on a river cruise, which was a fun way to see the attractions of Paris.Unfortunately you can either sit indoors and hear the tour but not bask in the sunlight, or outdoors and bask in the sunlight but not hear the tour.A glass of champagne might be pricey at EUR 10, but it is recommended - after all, you're in Paris!

AMA Waterways does it best!. Our weeklong journey on the Amalegro began on the Seine in Paris and carried us to Normandy for an interesting, beautiful trip up the Seine--or is it down the Seine. No matter, a wonderful experience!
nice in winter too. we took a relaxing cruise in the cold winter but it was really cosy inside the glass roof boat taking in all the best paris has to offer
A Great Experience!. A must see and do in Paris! Its great to be able to see paris from a cruise boat as you admire all the beauty it has to offer while relaxing on the river.

River of life. A walk down that river with a huge amount of beautiful buildings takes time, but enjoy that. We found a nice cafe where we enjoy a Cold beer and have that beautiful view over the river.

Relaxing way to see Paris. Great way to see the city from a different perspective & saves your feet! Gives a good idea of geography to help you plan a more detailed visit to different sites. Recommend to do early in your trip for this reason.

night cruise on river seine. uniquely parisian experience to see folks sitting on the riverside in the evening, took the night cruise that was one of the highlights of our trip, will come back to paris again to explore it further

fantastic treat boat trip. we took a riverboat trip, was amazing, its a great way to see lots of Paris but in a more relaxed way than by road or train and in good weather it was fab, see all the sights and have a hotdog an glass of wine on the boat, would do this again next time, but maybe for a longer one, this wasn't short but I could have stayed on a lot longer maybe do the hop on hop off one?
A river with Style. A beautiful river, where there are changing scenes / themes along the river at different times of the year.

Looks nice but smells of urine.. Every part of the steps leading to the river seem to be the local urinal. Absolutely stinks. Don't really see this in the pictures. Like any tourist city perhaps. Not my favourite place.
Fulfilled a grandmothers bucket list. Paris Plages, evening strolls, incredible dinner cruise ($$$ but one of those things you must do), perfect 3 days
interesting. take a boat and enjoy your time as the guide will explain to you the most important landmarks and places that the boat will passby
Locks of Love and more. It adds to the relaxing atmosphere of the Louvre complex and all the sites nearby. Great to stroll over the many bridges and refresh yourself...a real plus to the experience.

Pleasant river . What I loved the most about the Seine was how it is a vital part of the lives of Parisians. They enjoy it in many possible ways. We saw many people having their lunch, dinner by the river, or reading a book and relaxing. There were runners running alongside or even over it where there were small islands, walking passages and bridges. We almost regretted that we hadn't brought our running shoes with us. We will next time. We didn't miss out the chance to have picnic by the river though. On our second day we bought the most delicious French cheeses from Androuet and baguette from Kayser and then went by the river for a picnic. It was a lovely experience.

Spot on for seeing Paris from a different angle!. A great view of Paris, fab for restless children. We got to se lots of Paris we didn't have time to see individually. We got an hour's cruise, as part of a package, spot on!

Beautify River Seine. Recommend to take a River Seine Boat for touring the River. Enjoy the beauty of the historical buildings and bridges along the sides. You can see many Parisans walking along the river baths. Some enjoy sunbath under the sun with their beautiful friends. It is a very romantic trip. You may choose a not so popular River Seine cruise operator to avoid long queue.

Great sight!. Rode the Hop-on, Hop-off River Taxi, it was great. It was clean and a sight. You can see Lourve, Eiffel Tower, Notre Dame, Orsay, Love Lock Bridge... everything from the river. If you're on the river, you can get to everything you want to see from just following around the river.
Paris heat abated here. Breezes along the river made for nice walk. Paris was hot but the breezes along the river permitted enjoyment of the various neighborhoods and sites.
Take the boat tour, then stroll. We took a boat tour which was a great way to get an overview of the area. Then spend a few days walking around. Lots to see, very relaxing.

Take a walk along the banks. For any visit to Paris, whether you’ve seen it all or seen nothing yet, it’s always nice to walk along the Seine. At street level are lots of stalls with vendors selling trinkets, paintings, etc- fun to browse, very atmospheric. Closer to the bank, if you go down the steps, is a great place to sit and hang out. One area is more beach-like with plots of sand, and I saw a salsa/bachata party at one point. Definitely worth it to spend some time there.
NICE BOAT RIDE. We took the evening ride down the Seine. It was very crowded, but the trip was worth it. Pre-buy your tickets to eliminate some long lines.

Most romantic river in the world. I dream of standing on any one of the bridges, or walking the banks of the Seine. So beautiful! Gaze upon the architecture of Paris, the most magnificent city in the world.
Bateaux bus. Used the bateaux bus to navigate the shrine which is full of sights and landmark stops. The best way yo get around the city
Lovely!. We took a one hour boat trip and really enjoyed it. It's a great way to take in many of the city's beautiful sights.
River Seine Boat. Well worth going on a tourist boat that goes up and down the River Seine. Can be a long queue when waiting for the tourist boat, especially during holiday season
Peaceful. Best way to enjoy the river is by buying the hop on/off boat daily tickets - you get the best of both worlds as drop off points are by many of the main attractions
Magnificient. The Seine is very picturesque and divided the city in middle. Walks along the Seine are amazing. There are many bridges along the Seine to cross from one side to the other.

Beautiful by night .... We took an evening boat cruise along the river and really enjoyed seeing Paris change from day-to-night. The numerous bridges become illuminated and the historical buildings along the banks seem to come alive a little more. We also took an evening stroll along the Seine which was equally as enjoyable (and cheaper!).
Seine River Boat Ride. Great experience.......so many bridges.....Didn't like our boat and the ride was longer than we though it would be.....

Romantic visit. An hour river cruise under the famous bridges of the Seine gives you a good angle to see most of the famous buildings at a leisurely pace. Use one of the smaller boat services with personal commentary phones to get info on all key sights. This is much better than a noisy open top bus tour. You get a very good view from the river without jostling amongst the crowds.

I wouldnt miss a walk here!!!. Among all the good things you can do for free in Paris, this might be just one of the BEST ONES!!! A few years ago, the south bank of the river used to be a street that got closed, rearranged and made available for all pedestrians to enjoy more than 10km worth on nice views! If you have the stamina for it, just start a nice walk from the Eifel towers along the river all the way to notre dame and let the parisian feeling get into you. Youll find a lot of nice things along the way: the buildings and museums left and right, nice places to have a drink or eat, some of the most astonishing bridges in the world, etc etc etc.You can also get yourself a bike in one of the many Velib stations. Pick it there and return it somewhere else. It easy to book with your credit card, and very userfriendly and afordable. Or you can also just get yourself a ride in one the famous boats and let them do the guiding and you do the looking! Enjoy my running courtyard!!!! ;-)

Wonderful nighttime cruise to see the lights of Paris.. We took a nighttime Seine river cruise to see the lights of Paris. We sailed on the last cruise of the night. The tour guide was informative and the kids absolutely loved it. A word of warning: our cruise left several minutes early, leaving people that had purchased tickets and were there on-time but cut it too close on the dock. If this is the standard, make sure you get there a bit early.

Perfect for a cruise or scenic walk. We have enjoyed the Seine in many ways....A scenic sightseeing cruise of Paris (beautiful day or night, but especially at night), a multi-day river cruise beyond Paris, walking over the many varied bridges of Paris, or just strolling along the Seine.

Lovely and peaceful. We Walked along here when we visited notre dome as our apartment was in st marcel lovely walk, we also done a river cruise while visiting paris,we booked our tour at tourist information for £10 euros , great value for money, got to see some of the sights we hadn't had time to visit, our guide Grace was brilliant telling us lots of facts about different places, really enjoyed it, a must o

Nice relaxing ride. We booked the champaign tour and you sit on The front of the boat roped off from the other people, drinking champaign and enjoying the ride. If you can afford it, do it. You can book this along with the Effil Tower third level tour.
Relax on the Water. Great way to relax after summiting Eiffel and only a short walk away. Nice overview of historic sites along the Seine. Great for photos.

Take a River Cruise!. Many River Cruises leave from the piers near the Eiffel Tower and offer views of the Louvre, the Eiffel Tower, and Notre Dame from the river. They also go by the little garden on the West end of the Isle de la Cite where Grand Master Jacque DeMolay was burned at the Stake in site of Notre Dame back in the 1300's.. But, they don't tell you that.

MS Botticelli from Paris to Honfleur. 6 day cruise on the Seine aboard the MS Botticelli from Croisieurope.Great way to see the river from Paris all the way to Normandy and visit some picturesque places such as Honfleur, Rouen or take some tours like the Abbey Trail or the Alabaster Coast. The food was delicious, the crew was always nice and helpful and we ended up making new friends among the other passengers.

Good Rinda, Bad Rinda; Pay for Viking gold, get Viking bronze.. 1. Summary: After reading & watching the Viking advertisements and paying top dollar, we were disappointed; we paid for gold, but the Vikings delivered only bronze. We did see a lot of Paris and we did see a lot of other parts of northern France. However, the itinerary could have easily been adjusted to give more time in Paris, Versailles, and Normandy and less time in little villages/towns that were carbon copies of the other little villages/towns that we saw on the previous day. The food was mostly "ho-hum" average, with a few really great meals and a few total epicurean disasters. They filled our glasses with wine at every opportunity during lunch and dinner, and champagne was available at breakfast if we felt the need. On a scale of 1 (Poor) to 10 (Fabulous) we rated the trip at "6" and most of the other passengers that we talked with on the cruise were in agreement. The overall issue that drove us crazy was the schizophrenic nature of the cruise: one night we would get a truly great meal at dinner, but the next night was just awful; one day we would enjoy a very interesting and well planned guided tour but the next day we were left to wander a small town with yet another gothic church and not much else. If you're a zealous history buff, you may find everything to be exceptionally interesting, but how many gothic churches and former palaces can you visit in one week? France is littered with them. We would have preferred to have had more time at Normandy, the Louvre, and Versailles. Recommendations: Bring comfortable walking shoes and a hat, you will need them. If you plan to take this trip, please remember to put the camera or iPhone down once in a while and actually LOOK at the scenery, paintings, sculptures and other attractions with your own eyes. It's very easy to only see France through the 2-inch screen on the back of your camera and miss out on actually BEING there. We saw countless tourists solidly glued to their cameras throughout the tours, desperately trying to get the perfect picture of something or other, or hell-bent on getting a selfie with the Mona Lisa. I confess that I fell into that "give me photo or give me death" category more than once. Also, consider skipping lunch to spend more time in the venues; you can grab some quick ice cream or chocolate crepes or even eat at a cafe without having to take the bus back to the boat.Disclaimer: This was our first trip to Paris and/or France and our first vacation on a Viking River Cruise or any river cruise for that matter. We have previously taken two European vacations to Italy (Rome, Florence, Capri, Pompeii, Venice, Sorrento, and Assisi). We have been on 4 or 5 Royal Caribbean cruises (to the Caribbean) over the last 20 years, plus a Royal Caribbean cruise to Alaska and a cruise around the Hawaiian Islands. Also note that this trip took place in August; that's the month where most people in France head to the beaches and a whole lot of businesses are closed, especially the smaller "mom and pop" stores. Note: the French get at least 5 weeks of vacation each year, and they love to use it. The good news was that the traffic was dramatically reduced because everybody was out of town, and since we spent a lot of time sitting on buses, that time really added up. Also note that we were booked on the "Rinda", the larger boat that can't dock in downtown Paris, so they docked Rinda in Le Pecq which is a small town about 15 miles west of Paris. The Viking people like to refer to Le Pecq as "a suburb of Paris" but that's like calling Baltimore a suburb of Washington DC. They constantly told us that it only took 20 minutes to drive from Le Pecq to Paris, but the helicopter must have been in the shop while we were there since the trip was consistently 55 to 60 minutes one way every time we got on the bus; the red lights and construction zones didn't go on holiday. 2. Airlines - Getting There: They won't make your flight reservations when you sign up for the cruise and pay in full, so you have no idea of what arrangements are going to be made on your behalf until 30 days prior to the cruise. We flew out of Washington DC (Dulles) and they put us on an Iceland Air flight to Iceland (5.5 hours), and then another Iceland Air flight to Paris (3.5 hours). We had about one hour between flights in Keflavik (Reykjavik) where it was 40 degrees (F) at noon on the 3rd of August! Be prepared to be seated on the least expensive flights to and from Paris and for many this means hours of additional travel time; so when some passengers arrive on the ship they may not be in the best of spirits! It seemed that everybody we talked with ended up going through a different stop on the way to Paris. Some went through Iceland, some went through Heathrow/London, some through Munich, some through Stockholm. One couple was flying back home to Baltimore from Paris through Chicago with a 4 hour wait in Chicago. It was interesting that when we switched planes in Iceland, the authorities checked our passports, but when we landed in Paris, there was no immigration or customs; we went from the baggage carousel directly to the public areas of the airport where our Viking representative greeted us and herded all of the passengers into one area prior to getting on the bus for Le Pecq. 3. Does Le Pecq equal Paris? When we booked our vacation back in December, the other Viking River Boats were sold out so the Rinda was our only choice for the first week in August. The advertisements say "Paris, Paris, and Paris" but the Rinda is docked in Le Pecq (sometimes referred to by the Viking folks as the "Port of Paris"). It's a 1-hour Viking-provided bus ride to downtown Paris (Louvre, Notre Dame) one-way, so we felt cheated out of valuable time that could have been better spent in the city. The La Pecq issue has become an 800 pound gorilla in the room; we got a special letter prior to departure that explained and defended Viking's use of Le Pecq and the Cruise Director tried to explain away the issue while we were onboard. One good thing about Le Pecq, they have a Monoprix store there (like a Walmart - just a few steps from the dock) where we bought several bottles of wine and some chocolate to enjoy while sitting on our veranda watching the shoreline of the Seine go by. There is a small refrigerator in the cabin and you can stuff 4 or 5 bottles of wine into it; there is a corkscrew in every room. During meals, the waiters will be happy to open a bottle of wine that you provide if you want to go that route.4. Das Boat & Das Staff: We were in Cabin 335, an "A" Stateroom with the veranda. We had a king size bed with one chair, 2 end tables, a bureau for the clothes, a closet, a digital safe, a small refrigerator, and a flat screen TV. There was just enough room to walk around the bed. The bathrooms are small and the shower measured about 4 feet wide and 24 inches in depth at one end and 18 inches in depth at the other end. The larger staterooms include a sitting area and larger bathrooms and showers. The veranda was just wide enough for two chairs and a small table. We used the veranda during 3 days and 1 night for sipping wine and taking photos of the quaint villages/towns and scenery as we sailed down the Seine. The veranda became our favorite spot for private relaxation during travel time. If you don't get a veranda, the sundeck is always an option. The TV comes in handy; you can get CNN and BBC news, sports, Viking documentaries, maps of the cruise, movies and TV shows if you wish, but you can also listen to the Cruise Director's lectures in the room if you don't want to go up to the lounge before dinner. They also have a camera on the bow of the ship and you can watch the view on the TV 24/7. They provide a variety of music channels, and I found it amusing that what they call "Pop" music was mostly rock and roll from the 50s and 60s; I would have called that "Golden Oldies." The suitcases fit under the bed for storage, and a 220-volt hair dryer came with the room. You'll find three or four 110-volt outlets in the room along with three or four 220-volt outlets. They provided life jackets under the bed and a safety exercise was conducted the first afternoon, but they like to joke that if the ship goes down, they will be serving cocktails on the sun deck; the Seine is only about 9 or 10 feet deep in most places and the ship draws 6 feet of water so the boat doesn't have very far to go before hitting bottom and lifeboats are not required. Amazingly, the Seine is only about 100 yards wide in most places so you're never more than 40 or 50 yards from shore during the entire cruise. When it is necessary to turn the boat around, they have to cruise to a wide spot in the river, make the U turn and then cruise back to the ultimate destination. The Seine has 6 locks between Paris and Normandy (think "miniature Panama Canal") and it was very interesting every time we entered a lock and the boat went up or down about 12 feet in about 15 minutes. Tours of the wheelhouse are available over several days if you're interested in the technology; the boat has bow thrusters to help make turns or to dock, and they use radar even though the river is very narrow. 5. Where are the toilets? One of the first things that the Cruise Director (Michael B.) covered during the early daily briefings was the astonishing lack of public toilets all over France. We were warned to use any available rest rooms early and often because you would never know when and if you were going to find another one or how long the lines would be waiting to get into one. As a last resort, you might need to duck into a cafe, buy a glass of wine, and go stand in line at their unisex single-use restroom. "Depend" under garments might be a consideration for you! Unfortunately, because of the lack of facilities and the huge crowds at the venues, our group tours (typically 20 to 50 people) were delayed by 20 or 25 minutes every time we stopped for a potty break. At Versailles, the Louvre, Giverny, and Normandy, it wasn't unusual to see 10+ women waiting to get into the public ladies' rooms while there was no waiting at the men's room. Occasionally, we found rest rooms at a snack shop where they wanted 70 cents (cheaper than a glass of wine) to use the facilities when you can find them. 6. Paris: If you really want to "see Paris", you should consider booking a few days on the front end of the trip or the back end. We saw Notre Dame, the Louvre, and the Eiffel Tower (on the Viking excursions) and we walked mile after mile of Paris streets to visit some museums, stores and cafes on our own. We ended up spending 1 full day in Paris at the beginning of the trip and another full day (including a half day in Versailles) at the end of the trip. We do feel that by adjusting the schedule and reducing/ eliminating the time spent in Les Andeles, we would have enjoyed more time in Paris7. Itinerary: As our first priority, we wanted to see Paris, Notre Dame, the Louvre, Versailles and Normandy. The other stops on the trip were expected to be icing on the cake. We soon realized that Paris requires a lot more time than previously planned, and we were not prepared for the long bus rides and having to wait in lines for everything including restrooms. And, since some of the less-interesting stops ate up more time on the schedule, we felt cheated out of time that we could have spent on our primary objectives. (See the "Excursions" paragraph below.) So Bottom Line: It was an "OK" itinerary, but it could have been much better.8. Other Guests: The Rinda holds about 200 passengers. About 70 percent of the passengers appeared to be over 65. Maybe 10 percent of the passengers were under 30 with just a few under 18. The remaining 20 percent appeared to be between 30 and 65 years old. A few people were in wheel chairs or used a cane to get around. There are no tables for two on the Rinda, so unless you're travelling with a group, you'll be meeting lots of new people at every meal. So that you can prepare your answers in advance, here are the questions that are universally asked upon meeting unknown passengers: What is your name? Where are you from? Is this your first Viking Cruise? Where else have you traveled with Viking and around the world? What did you do before you retired? Where did you live before you retired? Are your children as deliriously happy, exceptionally smart, amazingly good looking, extraordinarily well educated, and hugely successful as our children? Note: If you intend to get creative with your answers, please coordinate with your travel partner(s) so that you all consistently tell the same fantasies during the cruise! Having said that, please note that we did meet five or six "very down to earth" couples who provided very pleasant dinner conversations and travel tips during the week. 9. Meals, Wines, and Lines: Our previous experiences on cruise ships always included excellent meals. The Vikings provided a few excellent meals, a few disasters, and mostly mundane fare. On top of that, the portions usually tended to be small with a few exceptions. I thought we had paid for "excellent" and "bountiful," but I guess I was mistaken. We learned a lot on the cruise. We discovered that by adding mushrooms and wine to chicken, you become a Coq au Vin chef, and adding a little cheese to cauliflower makes it "French Cauliflower." If you really want to impress your family, run your mashed potatoes through a pastry decorating bag, and then use a blowtorch to brown the top of the swirl; finally, jam a finger-sized piece of toast into the top of the swirl and you're ready for the kitchen on Rinda (smile). Spinach is "French spinach" when it is served in a pastry shell. If you buy wine, they will be happy to pull the cork for you - no problem, no charge.Dinners: The Split Pea soup was very good as was the French Onion soup and the Lobster/Shrimp Bisque (brown, not pink). The pork tenderloin was great. The Beef Wellington was very tasty but the meat was a little on the tough side, and the cheeseburger with fries was excellent; just like at the Outback Steak House. I had a prime rib dinner one night that was very good, but they served it with a little container full of BBQ sauce on the side. How strange; A1 steak sauce would have been much more welcomed. The Coq au Vin consisted of a leg and a thigh with some mushrooms and some kind of wine sauce; it was OK but the portion was on the small side. The plain chicken breast was a safe alternative but totally uninspiring. We tried to avoid ordering things that we didn't recognize on the menu. I ordered the penne pasta with shrimp one night and I got a large bowl of pasta with a plain tomato sauce that reminded me of SpaghettiOs eaten during my childhood, along with three (3) shrimp. Yes, I said three (3) medium sized shrimp. I was insulted and I should have sent it back but I didn't. Later in the week they served a shrimp cocktail appetizer that had 2 large shrimp, thus confirming my conclusion that three medium shrimp does not a meal make. That shrimp cocktail appetizer featured two large raw shrimp that were only partially deveined so I had to finish off the deveining task myself. I was tempted to cook the shrimp over the candle on the table, but I didn't want to make a scene on the Seine. One of our tablemates ordered the scallops one night and got four (4) golf ball-size scallops; the presentation was very nice but the portion size was "skimpy." The night after having the excellent cheeseburger, I decided to give the "Pulled Pork Sandwich with Cole slaw and fries" a try, and I ended up getting a Kaiser roll with a compressed pork patty that looked like a 3-inch pancake. The slaw came in a small cup with a few fries alongside. See photo below. Has this chef ever been to Texas? What was he thinking? At the very least, he could have done some research on the Internet. Salads are not typically served with dinner on Rinda, but if you ask, you can get a Caesar salad added to your order. The house wine flowed like water; the waiters refilled our glasses every 10 minutes like clockwork. We received some interesting appetizers; one was a teaspoon filled with some kind of fish chutney; somebody suggested that it was raw tuna but we never managed to verify that guess. I got the steak tartar one night - very thinly sliced raw beef with a tasty sauce. The thought of eating anything raw scares the heck out of me, but when in France, do as the French, right?Lunch: We skipped a lot of lunches to stay at the venue du jour and avoid spending time on the bus and sitting for an hour or more on the boat for lunch. Our Viking-provided lunch at a restaurant in Normandy consisted of wine, a salad, Coq au Vin, scalloped potatoes, some zucchini, cans of soda, and a chocolate dessert. Unfortunately, it took 1.5 hours to get through the Normandy lunch; that time would have been better spent at the museum. One day on Rinda, we stood in a line 10 deep (20 minutes) to get some French-sounding spaghetti thing for lunch. They put some olive oil in a skillet, added spaghetti, threw in some bland tomato sauce, and sprinkled some herbs on top. After simmering that for 4 or 5 minutes it was ready to eat. Again, the taste reminded me of childhood SpaghettiOs. If I ever go on another Viking cruise, I'll bring a jar of Ragu. The French are very big on having salads for lunch, and one day we did the Rinda lunch buffet which included salad, egg salad, pasta salad, some other salads, sausages, pickled herring, and cauliflower covered in cheese. Thankfully, the dessert table was exceptional and my willpower caved in as I sampled a large variety of cakes, pies, cookies, puddings, and candy. Hats off to the pastry chef; he never disappointed. If you're going to France for the wine and pastry you will be in heaven.Breakfast: Rinda serves a great breakfast. They make omelets to order at the buffet line but you might have to stand in line for 15 minutes to get one. Recommendation: Order an omelet from the waiter and you'll get in 3 or 4 minutes from the kitchen. You can also order pancakes, French toast (very dry), eggs, juices, eggs Benedict, and other items from the menu. The buffet selections were endless: champagne, omelets, scrambled eggs, bacon, sausage, oatmeal, granola, cereals, yogurts, pastries, bagels, toasted bread, croissants, smoked salmon, fresh fruits, hot stuff that I didn't recognize, some kind of crackers that I didn't recognize, muffins, you name it and it was there. We had absolutely no complaints when it came to breakfast, except that they could have cooked more than one omelet at a time at the buffet table to speed things up. 10. Airport & Driver Issues: Our bus drivers were pleasant, competent and punctual for almost all of the trips with the exception of our return trip to the airport on the last day. That particular driver was late arriving, texted and talked on her cell phone, and even started to read off the list of terminals that each passenger was headed to, all while driving at 60 mph on the highway. I was going to yell "put down that phone" while she was changing lanes with one hand, but I didn't know how to say that in French, and she didn't speak English! Also, the Viking representative at the airport took us to the wrong part of the terminal for our Iceland Air flight back to the US, and we would still be there if it wasn't for another passenger finding the ticket counter on his own and leading the way for the rest of us to the right part of the terminal. I think the Vikings are more worried about the arriving passengers than the departing passengers.11. Excursions: Excursions are good. One major issue when you're exploring on your own is having to wait in line for an hour or more when trying to get into a museum (usually a former palace) or other venue; that's not a problem when you're on a Viking excursion since they have group tour tickets with timed entry. Also, having a tour guide is really great since they know where the important stuff is located (it would have been very easy to get lost in the Louvre), they can give you the historical background, and they know where to find the restrooms. Unfortunately, after the (mostly) 2+ hour tours were over, we only got about 30-45 minutes of "free time" which is just enough time to visit the gift shop and hit the restroom before getting back on the bus; not enough time to really go off and explore. We tried to get around that problem in Paris by skipping the trip back to the boat for a lunch; that way we could spend more "free time" in Paris and catch the last bus back to the boat later that afternoon. We were lucky; the weather was perfect throughout the week except for a little light rain while we were inside the Louvre, but we didn't need the Viking-provided umbrellas at all. The Viking folks provide bottles of water every time you leave the ship - take a few - you'll need them.
