A number of very efficient and reaonably priced boat services operate on the river.Don't expect great views of the city as the river has high banks.The commentary is very brief and given in several languages so you have to listen carefully for your language each time a landmark is passed, after a short time most people just ignored the commentary.The boat cruise could be improved by offering a more detailed commentary of the amazing landmarks and history via a earphone or something similar.

Just as you imagine it.. Even in winter this river and its banks echo romance. We went on a twilight cruise and were mesmerised...excellent commentary too. Walking along the banks of the Seine is just like being in a movie.
walk it and bike it. It is the spine of Paris and its heart. Morning through the late night it's beauty and vibrancy are not to be missed and experienced, day and night, trip after trip.

The Paris By Night experience. Forget the Tiber, Hudson or Thames ... The Seine in Paris is a perfect way of seeing lots of Paris : Eifel tower, Notre Dame Or more modern structures like the bibliotheque National or Bercy. During the day it is nice to go up and down the river, but at night after dark, you will be in awe by the beauty of the city of light. If you combine it with a nice dinner or one of the party boats, it will be an,unforgettable experience (bring your camera) !!!

The top attraction in Paris. You can walk the seine on the left or right bank or take a cruise on the batobus (cost 14 Euros) that is good all day and allows you to hop on and off to visit all th esites in Paris convenient to the Seine. The city revolves around the river and the city has done a great job making this the top attraction in Paris. We visited London and Rome on our trip and the Seine is the best river in the three major capital cities.

Treat yourself a mini cruise along river seine!. I like the feeling of floating around Paris, the experience is different day and night. I think the day cruise is better.. Food is quite expensive aboard, but i think it's worth it..

Allison W. In the summer take a picnic down to the left Bank and join all the Parisiens doing the same. Enjoy the view of Notre Dame as you listen to free Jazz or someone playing the guitar. Forget the over-priced evening boats, get a 1,2,or 3 day tickets for the BateauBus and enjoy unlimited trips on the Seine between all the major attractions.
Seine River. The river is very nice and quick flowing. You can get some terrific shots when walking over the bridges.
Ice Cream Island. Wonderful place to walk or sit and eat an ice cream

Just as imagined. Such history along this river. No trip to Paris is complete without visiting the Seine. Even though it was December, the sights were lovely. Want to return when the artists are there.
Good. Go on a river cruise in the evening. One could also dine while cruising on the river

Do the River Cruise!. We loved it~ we took the Bateaux Parisiens 1 hour cruise. The water levels were high, so we could only go down to the bridge before the Notre Dame, but they took us farther down the other end, and we got to see the little Statue of Liberty. It was perfect timing, as we turned around, we could see the Statue of Liberty and the Eiffel Tower twinkling at the same time! What a sight!
It is the heart of Paris. The sight seeing by way of ferry on river seine is the best. The pass is available where you can get on... get off whenever you desire.
Lovely River Cruise. A lovely way to view Paris from the water for 1 and a half hours at approx 14 Euros .

Great Views. We spent some time on the Seine, both on the Bateaux cruise and the Batobus river taxi. Great views of the city. Also, interesting to walk along the left bank and visit some of the stores there.

See half of major Paris monuments in one hour.. Running through the heart of Paris the Seine has always been pivotal in the history of Paris. Many one hour boat trips with usual superficial audio commentary so worth spending half an hour with your guide book filling in the details before you set off. Dorling Kingsley guide has an especially good semi aerial annotated map of the river. Trips from Eiffel tower or Pont d'Alma. If you have time take one of the Bateaux Mouche boats with lunch included.

Take a boat trip between the major sites. If you are limited for time, take a boat trip between the major sites or jump on and off where you want if you have time to spare.A 2 pass on site seeing buses is even better if you have enough time.
the livingroom of Paris.. Such fun in the summertime. A tour guide described the Seine as "every Parisian's living room" and it's very true! Wonderfully social and interesting.
A romantic walk. Walking along the Seine and across the various bridges is a great way to pass an evening or day in Paris.
It's everywhere. If you're in Paris, you will cross this river eventually. The bridges are beautifully kept, and give a lovely romantic view of the city.

Interesting River Facts. Enjoyed the river cruise and all the fascinating facts about the many bridges that cross the Seine River. I think the most interesting thing about the cruise was that our guide spoke four different languages during the whole tour. That was quite amazing to me.

Great for walkers or jogger (watch out for con artists)!. Self explanatory & great walking. Just watch out for the con artists & beggars you will find en route (esp near central Paris attractions).A common scam is dropping a fake gold ring (brass) as you pass, giving it to you, then dodging back & asking for the "price of a coffee" in return. The best advice is ignore & keep walking... I don't think the scam is much more than an elaborate form of begging (and you may well see sleeping bags for the homeless under some of the bridges so some sympathy is inevitable). I have NEVER felt physically threatened by such people in Paris (UK beggars can be so much more physically intimidating although a violent disposition is uncommon amongst such people in France).Whether you do just give a Euro or two is down to your own judgement (but don't bother if it means dragging your wallet or purse out, as who knows... it might get swiped).. Watch your pockets at all times but don't let it spoil your fun...My advice is just to be careful, and try to enjoy any such experience as part of the wondeful quirkiness that is Paris...
Big River. A very wide river that you can tak a cruise on and enjoy the sights from a different angle see the working barges taking their wares along this gem
beautiful. besides being beautiful, this river has so much history on its banks... be sure to take a boat along it, you can see so many sites that way

Romantic.. Walked the River a bit. Last time we took the Bateaux Mouches dinner cruise in 1998 and it was well worth the tariff. No wonder it's called the city of lights. Walk the left bank until you get tired and take a taxi back to your hotel. We've found that taxis or the Metro are the way to get around Paris. We have also found that Parisians are freindly, but watch your back - there are pickpockets out there!

Both day and night.. Do what you have to do.1) Walk down either side of the bank during the day.2) Return back for the boat trip at night.Boat trips can be taken at the Bateau Parisiens, near the Eiffel tower. Definitely worth it, and brings back alot of movie screencaps. P/s: Remember to return for the night view at the eiffel tower. Watch it sparkle and shimmer!

Breathe in what it means to be in Paris. You will probably stroll along the Seine by default during the day time, as you visit Notre Dame Cathedral, and the other sites on the Ile de la Cite and the Ile St. Jacques.Make your visit to Paris all the more memorable by returning after dark to the banks of this romantic, historic river. Visit the Monoprix or other grocery store nearest your hotel, and pick up a bottle of wine (don't forget a cork screw), a baguette and a wheel of brie. If you want to make the evening even more authentically Parisian, pick up your baguette at a local boulangerie (baker) and the cheese at un fromagerie (cheese shop). Take the Metro, line #4 and get off at Cite. Stroll down to the Left Bank, around Notre Dame for the best sights and most enthusiastic company. You'll find the river bank lined with Parisians and other tourists, also with wine, bread and cheese in hand, celebrating the wonder of spending a night in this beautiful place. Sit, pop open your bottle of wine. Slice a few pieces of bread and delicious creamy cheese and enjoy the beauty of the river, the well lit nearby Cathedral, and the tour boats passing by.
Still a great walk on either bank. The river remains the heart of the city. We stayed on L'Ile St Louis, and the river makes it like a small village with its own tempo. Lovely.
The Seine. A great place for a stroll. So romatic and peaceful.

Postcard pretty. Wherever you are along the banks of the Seine river you get the same impression: you've seen it before ! It;s because this river is so famous-it's precisely what you expect it to be, only better ! A trip on a bateau mouche is mandatory to see the sights at night-they all have strong spotlights to help you catch the best sights. I wouldn't advise a dinner cruise-the menu can be disappointing. You'd better spend that money afterwards in a bistrot of your choice ashore-it comes cheaper anyway ! Some say the Seine is smelly-maybe in the summer; we were there in November and it was great. Don't forget the bridge of Alexander III !
Nice!. A boat tour down the Seine is a great way to see the city. Not too happy with some of the smells but this is definitely a must.

You must go on a boat cruise. This river is part of the character and soul of Paris. Make sure you make it part of your itinerary. We used Bateau Parisiens at the wharf next to the Eiffel Tower. Very good valuecheck out the website: http://www.bateauxparisiens.com/
Beautifiul. What can one say about the Seine and the city, beautiful! It's amazing how many sightseeing boats there are on the river.

When in Paris, don't miss a walk along the riverside of the Seine. The Seine river literally surrounds the heart of Paris. We walked along the south bank of the Ile de la Cité (city island) westward, starting at Pont St. Michel - a nice stroll. At that site there is a wide footpath very close to the waterfront.One of the best views of the river you have from the Pont des Arts (also known as the "lover's bridge, famous for the padlocks attached to its railings), where you can see both arms of the river embracing the Ile de la Cité.

Relax and take it in. Sitting by the River is relaxing and great people watching. Parisiennes use the river walk as a sidewalk so strolling is in order. If you have the time and money - taking a cruise on the River especially at night is so worth it. You will truly know why this is the City of Lights when you see at night from the river.

Take a river cruise.. The Seine River. Separates Paris into the Right and Left banks. Try to take a cruise which is a lovely experience (day or night) and walking across the different bridges (Pont Neuf for example is fun too.
Do the boat ride at night. We did the ride and saw Paris lit up with great introduction by tour guide. Saw the Eiffel Tower all lit up too.

Magical. When u take one of the Bateaux mouches trips....u will enjoy PARIS....and the Seine river from another perspective....with the beautiful frensh love songs.....you will feel like magically in a dream!!!

One hour trip from the Eiffel Tower.. Inexpensive (11e) comprehensive narrated trip with explanations given between pointing out the attractions. This was an early evening cruise and the waiting time was minimal
Night Ride. Try to go in the night or in the sunset very beautyful!!

3 ways to sense the Seine. No Paris trip would be complete without a stroll to River Seine, the most artistic river round the world. The extreme beauty of River Sense, however, might not be easily discovered with one trip alone. Thankful to experiencing the river thrice on 3 different means of transportation, I brought home a full-pledged sense of this wonder-landscape.1. My first touch onto River Sense was in the morning when I walked along the north west starting from the Eiffel Tower on the New York Ave to the Notre Dame. It took me 3 hours to pass strings of adorable landmarks. Among were Pont de Alexander III the most sophisticated bridge round the globe, Concorde Square with Egypt Obelisk, Tuleries Garden where you can view Montmartre, Museum Louvre, Pont de Art with myriad love locks while the magnificent Notre Dame is on the historic island where the first Paris was found and emerged towards the 2 banks of River Sense. Roam and pause till you learn some historic remarks of the river.2. River Sense becomes most dynamic and happening during the lunch time. On the bus from Luxembourg Garden via Latin Quarter and Saint Michel to Champs Elysee, I found the river turns out to be the center of Parisian life. Hoards of tourists, businessmen, students and retirees were strolling, boating, fishing, reading, eating and resting there as if it were their second home ever since.3. The best is yet to come though. The sun goes down to let River Sense shine best. Taking a boat at the Pont Neuf from 8pm to 9pm, I watched the City of Light changing its hues along sparkling River Seine. Romance feeling, music and unpotrayable Eiffel Tower by night would be simply among the fantastic await you thereon. You ought to enjoy the view to the fullest when the boat embarks in the sunset because the Seine would be not the same when you come back.
Hop On Hop Off. This is the way to see Paris in a day! Do the River Hop on Hop off. Batobus Paris. 13 Euro per person, on and off as many times as you like. 8 stops, GREAT investment

Do walk along the river.... If you are planning to visit Paris,walking along the river Seine should surely be on your itinery.Me and my family walked along the river .As you walk there are many bridges you will come across.One such bridge is where many locks are there which are tied by lovers who visit it.If you are there with your lover,do go on this bridge.Also as you walk there are many artists who draw sketches.These sketches are very beautiful and I so regret that I couldn’t buy one as I thought we will be able to buy these sketches somewhere else later .On our last day after visiting Eiffel we had some time so we sat on the riverside and had our lunch which was another beautiful experience.There are many cruises also but I didn’t go on them,you can think of going on them.
A great way to see paris. We went on a seine cruise and it really is the best way to see paris and Lois Island
its paris.love it. took a cruise...for 1 hour.was fine again do the hop on hop off great deal..have done it wish i did it again.great value! same price as 1 hr cruise..thats all the time we had left!

Views and People. Enjoyed looking at vendors wares. Walking along the river and across the river took us to anything we wanted to see. I liked looking at the beautiful details of the bridges. At night, we saw people living on boats.

Must do a boat trip!. Whatever else you do in Paris, find the time to do one of the many boat trips - gives you a chance to rest your legs and you get to see so many of the famous sights from the river!

Beautiful place to walk and appreciate your surroundings. Take a river cruise at night and truly enjoy the beauty of this city.
It is also a gorgeous place to walk during the day, we tried to organize most of our day trips to incorporate going along the river at some point as we really loved it

Because Paris you make my heart skip a beat. Yes, Paris if generally rated really high but it is worth every exaggeration every sigh and every pause. If you ever want to reconsider that take the cruise on River Seine, I opted for the Paris City Pass (which I highly recommend) and the river cruise was a part of the trip. The Bateaux Parisiens River Cruise was a part of the cruise and I really enjoyed it, it was pretty cold and the river cruise runs ferry every half hour. Every ship has a glass enclosure a and a deck. I was travelling with my friend and we both chose to sit on the deck although it was cold there were fewer people and we could take in Paris unlike the rest of the trip. The beauty of Musée d'Orsay and generally the banks of the Seine remains unparalleled in my memory. We availed to the Enchanting Tour and was very satisfied with it.The trip originates from Eiffel tower and runs every half hour, if you are using the Paris City Pass you can just hop in, for all others it is pretty easy to buy a ticket just before hopping on. I suggest that you take the trip around 5.00 pm it is a very good time considering the colors of the sky are changing which generally makes it prettier

Romantic. Grab a bottle of wine, a picnic and find any place your heart leads you to relax on the river. Slow down, enjoy the moment and watch the boats filled with tourists go by. Enjoy the locals who know that time slowed down and enjoyed is the best time. We start and end our trip by always slowing down, sitting down by the river with a bottle and food and enjoy Paris.

A nice introduction to the area. No matter how much time you spend in Paris, the Seine becomes an important reference point for locating where you are relative to anywhere else, either visually or on a map. It snakes through the center of the city past many major sites, and so it makes sense, then, that a cruise along the river is considered a must-do event, romantic even. Having done this twice, here is what we have learned: 1) It's a relatively inexpensive and quick way to get the lay of the land and see several monuments (from a distance). 2) Crowded boats can hamper your enjoyment of the cruise, so find out when the slow times are (they run continuously throughout the day and night, depending on season). 3) Be sure to get a spot on the left side of the boat, especially if you take a night cruise. Most of the things that are described on the audio tour are on the left side, and if you are on the right side you might not be able to see what is being discussed. 4) You can move around the boat, so don't worry if you don't grab the seat you want right away, you can always change. 5) In my opinion, the daytime cruise was more enjoyable than the night time cruise.We took our tours with Bateaux Parisiens, directly across the street from the Eiffel Tower. No meal, just cruise with audio guide. It takes about an hour and it is fun if it's your first time in Paris. The only other thing I'd mention is that these tours are expressly designed for tourists, and so it is one of the few places where we felt herded through. Still, it's worth doing. Once.
Beautiful!. My husband and I did the river cruise on our first night in Paris. It was a great way to get oriented with the city. I think it is a must do.

A must do. strolled the seine many times during my stay in Paris was a great way to see the city, take some pictures, and just enjoy a relaxing stroll. I didn't have a problem with street vendors and I walked several times, at different times of the day, and both week days and weekends. I walked from Notredame area, to the effile tower area never with a problem. Since i was on a budget I would often grab a take-away lunch and just go sit by the river to eat. There is one bridge I don't know the name it's a pedestrian bridge and it's cover in love locks. These are all types of locks the couples write thier names on then attach them to the bridge amazing to see, my boyfriend and I made one last minute with a lock from a local store and a borrowed marker but some people get really into and come prepared with engraved customized locks. I recomend doing it if you're going in a couple it was just a sweet romantic touch to the trip.

Thoroughly Enjoyed the River Cruise!!!. Oh this was a wonderful experience! When I go back to Paris I want to go on the River Cruise again. We sat very comfortably as you take in by boat the BEAUTIFUL architecture in this city. Tre Manifique!!!! :)

River Cruise down the Seine is a MUST!. Whatever you do in Paris, take a cruise down the Seine. We went at night and it was just fantastic! Between the lights and the architecture of the bridges, it was an unforgettable experience!

River Cruise Paris to the Landing Beaches of Normandy. We took a one week Seine River cruise from Paris to the Landing Beaches of Normandy .Paris was wonderful but the cruise portion of our trip was superb.The Landing Beaches especially Juno Beach was a very MOVING UNFORGETTABLE experience.We saw Pegasus bridge and the Canadian and British cemetaries.Passing through the French countryside was lovely.We visited Claude Monet`s gardens and the home where Van Gogh spent his last few months .Also we visited Honfleur a lovely harbour town

The artery of Paris. We orientated ourselves according to the river; walked along it; had sundowners on it's banks; watched people who lived on it; had an evening sightseeing cruise on it and learnt interesting stories about the bridges that cross it. The beautiful Seine.

A wonderful and unfrgettable experience.. There are numerous ways to take a ride on the Seine. We chose twilight time and it became dark while we were on the boat. It is a great way to start your first visit to Paris. It gives you a good idea of where the attractions are and how far they are one from another. We took a boat that started its tour from near Pont Neuf. We had an English speaking tour guide. She did a great job. Many places of interest are visible from the Seine and at night they are wonderfully lit - you will go by Louvre, D'Orsay, Eiffel Tower, Notre Dame and the "Little Island". It is also fun to watch young people hanging out on the embakments. We were concerned that the upper deck was already full, but then the lower deck was great too - it was pretty open and was less crowded.

Nite Boat Cruise Fave thing to do in PARIS. Dont' miss the nite time cruise down the Seine, it is the most beautiful sight to see the city of LIGHTS, bring your camera, our best pictures were on the boat cruises. Bring a bottle of wine and toast, or make a wish under the many bridges...Don't miss it...wonderful memories!!!!

Go on a boat tour. I would recommend doing a boat tour your first day in paris as it will give you a general overview of paris and you will find many great attractions on your boat tour. You do not have to have dinner you could just go on to discover the great sights of paris. A must do attraction in paris, kids would enjoy this attraction

Inexpensive Dinner Cruise. On a whim my wife and I went on an inexpensive dinner cruise on the Seine river one evening while in Paris. We hadn't planned it, deciding to do it only as we passed by the departure point of a particular tour operator while walking along the river. This particular boat had leather chairs arranged in pairs with small round tables for each chair that pivoted out of the way. There are tables right near the window (where we sat) and another level above. The seating was a little cramped (not a lot of leg room) but acceptable. We had a choice of drink when we bought the tickets (at extra cost) - we chose wine, which came in individual 250ml (25cl) bottles (for 6€ over the base 29€). There was also a choice of chicken or fish for the entree, served with rice. I chose the fish (salmon), which turned out to be quite good. My wife is a vegetarian and before we decided to take the dinner cruise we had been assured by a dock-side "representative" (salesman) that she would be accomodated. We were hoodwinked. Her "vegetarian" meal consisted of two helpings of rice instead of one. They had nothing else on the boat, not even vegetables. Thankfully, this particular dinner cruise was not expensive (relatively speaking). And it was otherwise a pleasant experience. However, because the banks of the Seine are so built-up, apart from the Eiffel Tower what you see from the boat is not nearly as impressive as what you see from a boat on the Thames in London, in my opinion.

Bateaux Mouches!. At last I followed the advise of many....to do a River Seine experience the first day in Paris.it is a beautiful experience and gives you an idea of Paris and you pass by so many bridges and so many beautiful places.The Bateaux Mouches was great, no dinner just the great sights!

Some lovely walks, choose your area carefully. Taking some time to walk along the River, is a lovely way to soak up Paris. Just make sure you do it in an area where there are not any street sellers and slightly away from all the other tourists, so you get a bit of space to yourself! We ended up walking from the eiffel Tower and east along the river, past Pont Alma and to Pont Alexandre III. A couple of days prior we had tried to walk west along the banks of the River from the Notre Dame. This was absolutely chaos, people bumping into you and being pushed off the pavement - it really wasn't enjoyable. The other thing to do is walk along the banks and keep crossing over the river on the bridges, that way you get some lovely views from either side. There are plenty of lovely walks to do....and the best thing is that they're free !!

le capitaine fracasse food was a disappointment. For our trip to paris we booked a river seine dinner cruise to celebrate my 30th birthday. After reading online reviews, I selected Le capitaine fracasse as it had positive reviews and was moderately priced. Unfortunately the food was a huge disappointment and for 80 euros per person definitely not worth it. It was pre-made and kept in warmers, just like airline food. in fact our Air Tahiti meal on the flight over tasted better. We ordered the fish and steak plates. Both were flavorless, and overcooked. The service however was very good and of course the experience of dining on the river seine at night was magical. Our sincere recommendation is to take a river seine cruise, however save your money and do not book a meal cruise. Either have dinner before or after on land, and take a cocktail cruise or non meal cruise.

Capitaine Fracasse dinner cruise on the Seine - very disappointing. We were really disappointed with this trip and did not feel it was anywhere near worth the money. Most of the food was indeed excellent. The starters and desserts were exceptional, but the main course let it down. We paid an extra 10 Euros each for the fillet beef which was extremely tough.One of the biggest disappointments, however, was the attitude of the staff. The whole event felt like a rushed, perfectly timed money-making escapade with little attention to customer service.Worst of all was that we felt we had been conned because the website was so inaccurate. We pre-booked windows in the front bay section at 10 Euros per person, and had an email confirmation of this, but when we arrived they seated us halfway back along the side of the boat and tried to charge us an additional 30 Euros. They have now launched a new version of the website, however, which is more representative of costs and seating arrangements but I would not be at all confident that you will actually get what you request. Another significant criticism is that the interior of the boat is lit so brightly that it's difficult to see out when it's dark because you just get the reflection of all the inside lights in the windows. They really do need to dim the interior. The best view is if you go up onto the outside top deck between courses. If the weather is nice it's absolutely spectacular.The 2 hour experience on board Capitaine Fracasse cost us 180 Euros (approx £150) and it certainly wasn't worth that. An evening trip down the Seine is a must - beautiful views, very romantic and relaxing, especially after dark, But my advice would be to eat in a nice little restaurant ashore first and then hop on one of the Bateaux Mouches where you get a 1 hour 15 minute cruise for just 10 Euros. You can sit up on the top deck and have the same spectacular views for a fraction of the price and a lot less hassle.

Tour cruise on a parisian boat. I would recommend the parisian boat for a tour cruise along the seine in paris. I had lunch there, on one of the boat during a cruise, the food was decent, not tremendous, but truly it was worth it. The view is great and it's well organized, you will definitely have a nice time.

Le Capitaine Fracasse Dinner Cruise 'FANTASTIC'. We went to Paris to celebrate my fathers 60th birthday. I booked the cruise on line from the UK. As it was a special occasion I paid extra for a table in the window and a birthday cake. I received an email confirmation almost immediately after booking, to be on the safe side I phoned to confirm although I only got the answer phone.Fortunately on arrival everything went to plan, we had a fabulous table at the front of the boat and we were made very welcome.The food was amazing and plentiful, I had decided we would have the 69 euro meal which included a delicious cocktail on arrival, starter, main, pudding, coffee and wine. One thing to be made aware of, is that if you choose the steak you'll be charged an extra 10 euros. Although with all the added extras this wasn't a 'cheap' meal out, it was worth every penny and dad had the most fantastic birthday.

A world of history in the banks of a river. amazing, dramatically beautiful, a gift to the eyes. I cant say in words all the emotions you feel once you get the banks of the Seine and you make a trio from Bastille to Eiffel and see one and another monument, old bridge, palace, and the proper river, is amazing, I took a Batobus in Orsay Quai and take the next stations to notre dame, then i took the back in the other side of the river in Hotel de Ville Quai and took towards le Tour, i cant say in words this experience, probably a luxe before than now is on the reach of whoever in the price of 12 euros by the batobus. A regular river service that is not guided.

Iconic and romantic .... My husband and I did a river boat tour down the Seine while we were in Paris and I'm so glad we did. We saw a lot of sights from the boat and the ride was breezy and romantic. We had a short time in Paris and this was one of the highlights.

Le Capitaine Fracasse River Seine Dinner Cruise... Fantastic!!!. This dinner cruise was the highlight of our trip and the best meal I had in Paris. The chef is truly gifted and the boat itself was gorgeous inside and out. We had the three course meal with wine, starting with a complementary cocktail and ending with coffee. The appetizer included a sampling of 5 small plates including hazelnut soup that was delicious. For our main course, we had duck and chicken with excellent sides, and we finished with the chocolate cake and berry tart for dessert. Everything was divine and the view was great. The only thing is that we weren't quite sure what all the attractions were because there is no narration as you cruise by the sights, but we figured it out by the end of our trip and also, it is kind of hard to find (Just take the bridge before the Eiffel Tower and walk to the middle of it, until you find the steps that go down to a small isle and it will come right to the deck at the precise time). Definitely worth the money and not a tourist trap at all. In fact, most of the people that were on the boat with us were locals.

Walk All the Bridges and Quais of Paris; You Won't Be Disappointed. My wife and I have walked all the bridges and quais of Paris, from the Pont d'Austerlitz in the East to Pont Mirabeau in the West. This is the true heart of Paris. We like to say we are Left Bank people, but you have to spend time on both sides of the Seine to appreciate this most wonderful of all cities. Here are some highlights. Quai des Célestins is the Marais overlook on the Seine - views of the dome of the Pantheon from sidewalk cafes here. Quai de Montebello, one of my favorite spots in the world; in the shadows of Notre Dame along the left channel of the Seine. I've dined aboard the Kiosk Flotant (a floating cafe that plies the Seine in Paris) here on glorious sunny afternoons. Above is the Shakespeare and Company bookshop; and all along the quais, many bookstalls. Pont Neuf ("new bridge" - perhaps it was when it was built, but it is one of the oldest still standing, built in 1604) looks like a foritfication across the river, with its multiple turrets. It is the only bridge that crosses the Île de la Cité without changing names.My favorite is the Pont des Arts, or Passerelle des Arts. It is a footbridge that crosses from the Institute of France to the Louvre. Upstream, it has a great view of Pont Neuf and Notre Dame beyond. Downstream, it is a wonderful spot for viewing the Eiffel Tower as it lights up at night.At the Port du Louvre, the walls between the river and the street along the Quai François Mitterrand give way to a view of the Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel between the Louvre and the Tuileries. Pont de la Concorde spans the Seine between the National Assembly and Place de la Concorde, with its Egyptian obelisk that marks the Eastern end of the Champs-Élysées. Quai d’Orsay is special to me for the Musée d'Orsay above it; the converted train terminal that now houses a great collection of Impressionist paintings.The most beautiful bridge in its own right is the Pont Alexandre III. It extends from the green expanse of Esplanade des Invalides on the Left to the exhibition palaces on the Right. Along with the Eiffel Tower, they were all built for the Exposition of 1900. Pont Alexandre III is lavishly decorated with art nouveau street lamps, cherubs and gold plated spirits of arts, sciences, industry and commerce atop tall columns.Next of note downstream is Pont de l'Alma; on the Right Bank end is Place de l’Alma, where the gold plated flame centerpiece has been surrounded by flowers and memorials to Princess Diana since her fatal accident in the adjacent tunnel. This square is another place where people gather to watch the flickering lights of the Eiffel Tower light up each night.The Pont d’Iena crosses between the Eiffel Tower and the Palais de Chaillot at the Trocadero Gardens. The Pont de Grenelle crosses Swan Aisle near where the model for the Statue of Liberty graces its downstream point. Then finally comes Pont Mirabeau. Apollinaire wrote:“Under Pont Mirabeau flows the Seine And our loves Must I remember themJoy always followed after painLet the night fall and the hours ringThe days go away, I remain”And as for this writer, his heart will always remain in Paris, about which Gertrude Stein said, “America is my country, but Paris is my home town.”

Avalon scenery France River Cruise. Last summer we had the holiday of a lifetime (I say that with practically every holiday we go on!). We were independent travellers on a Rhone-Soane cruise with the newest boat, the American Avalon Scenery. Very posh, slick and exciting. Sage was our tour operator, the rep actually got in touch and met us at the local station and escorted us on board, before the group arrived. Big plus. I loved all the inclusive tours. It was busy, which my husband did not like and the company of our Saga friends and Americans, New Zealanders and Australians was excellent. My particular grouse was how can such a pretigious boat offer a doube room with two single beds pushed together? Also the food was great but not exciting. I think they catered for middle road and I could have done with more garlic and adventurous cooking. My husband loved it! Well river crusing is so much better than ocean cruising, no crowds and plenty to see whilst cruising and the ability to hop off when moored. Just about to have a complete change and try a character boat the "Anancoluthe" just 50 passengers travelling Seine'Oise waterways.

Ahh the River Seine. If you are walking around Paris you will not miss the River Seine. The movies have made the River Seine iconic and a must see. Don't forget to walk near the banks, stand on the bridges as ships go under, and see it at night for a romantic evening.

Dinner cruise-Paris. The River is beautiful and I would definately take the time out to do this while in Paris. Whatever you do don't book the Sat night dinner cruise which runs from the Marina just across the road from the Eiffel Tower and down the steps on your right hand side if your looking at the tower...called La Marina Des Paris.We were told to meet at the marina for 7.30pm, waited and watched some beautiful dinner cruises pass us with candle lit tables and people eating, dressed smart with live music. Our boat turned up 50 minutes late (good job the weather was warm) no apologies on the late arrival from the captain. The boat was more like a canal boat from the 70's with tired worn carpets and curtains, little space and bright interior lights. We sailed down the Sienne listening to YMCA and disco music. The food was definatley not worth the money and they try to just fill you up on lots of bread, on a positive you do get a bottle of wine which was nice and the waiter service was also very good.My partner and I thought the whole thing was hilarious (comedy sketch) sailing past the Bataeux Mouches boats which were wonderful and what we expected, I'm sure they were laughing at us trying to see past the bright interior lights.Anyway, I would definately do but book with the Bataux Mouches, enjoy.

One of the best destinations!!!. River Seine is one of the best destinations in Paris. You can actually see all the corners of Paris during the "Bateau Mouche" cruise. The cruise usually lasts for one hour where the boat takes you under the 16 bridges that connect Paris. I remember listening to all Edith Piaff songs during the cruise; it brought good memories and made the experience and unforgettable one.I'd recommend a cruise during sunset since you'd be able to enjoy sightseeing and at the same time you would definitely enjoy a romantic and very unique sunset in the middle of the fascinating river.

Classic Paris. When in Paris, we love to stroll the banks the Seine. Sitting and watching the water, relaxing and soaking up the sun is classic Paris.On our last trip, we brought a bottle of wine down to the Seine and sat in the little park under Pont Neuf. As we drank our wine in the afternoon sun we read a book and soaked up the best of Parisian life.More on our time in Paris:http://justanothertravelblog.blogspot.com/2009/09/parisian-life.html

Pleasant way to sightseeing. When your feet need a break from walking but without missing out on sightseeing, hop onto a boat for a cruise down the Seine. This year I chose Vedettes de Paris which are just down the steps from the Eiffel Tower (right side when looking at the Tower from Trocadero). They do a running commentary in both english and french and any other language-just have to ask. It lasts an hour. They have a nice place to pick up a sandwich or warm food plus drinks before getting onto the boat, much better than what you can buy round the Tower. The boat also has food available and a bar.A tip for UK visitors; you can get a coupon with your Tesco vouchers to exchange for a ticket at the booth. At only £3 this is a great bargain compared to the 11€ normal fare.

Perfect for walking and picnics but disappointed with the cruise. Love the fact that you can stroll along the river any day and have picnics anytime, however I expected more from the boat cruise.For 10 Euros we took a boat cruise during the evening and although it was nice to see Paris at night I was disappointed that there was no tour guide to point out the various attractions. This is what I expected and we didn't get it. I spent 5 days in Paris and walked around at night, no need for me to sit on a boat to see the various attractions if I'm not getting any audio guide to tell me what I'm looking at. That's my opinion.
Don't miss this trip down the Seine!. Definitely a must do. We took the Bateaux Mouches, sat on the top, and had a wonderful time. It is certainly well worth the 10 Euros. Best buy in Paris.

Beautiful Cruise Ride. We took one of the cruise tours down the river and it was beautiful. really relaxing ride and very nice. A lot of major Paris attractions sit on the river so there are plenty of things to see. Sit on the outside of the boat for the best picture opportunities or on the end inside if you don't want to be outside.

Take the cruise. We really enjoyed this. It was an hour long cruise. You get a large phone to listen to the commentry (in 8 different languages) of where the boat is taking you and tells you the history of all the monuments or places you pass by. We took it at night, and it was amazingly romantic.

Batobus - River Taxi. Used the Batobus (river taxi/bus) to get around the city in April 2003. You can buy a single trip ticket, one day or two day pass. The two day pass is by far the best value for money which means you can hop on and off as often as you like. It is a great way to see the Seine and the left and right banks and delivers you to many of the top attractions. The stops are as follows: Notre Dame (Latin quarter), Jardin des Plantes, Hotel de Ville (City hall and Pompidou Centre), The Louvre (and Royal Palace), Champs Elysee (Pont Alexandre III), Eiffel Tower (Trocadero and Military school), Orsay Museum and finally onto St-Germain-des-pres.The service runs from April to October.10am - 7pm April, May and October.10am - 9pm June, July, August and September. Boats leave approximately every 20 - 25 minutes.
